Award.AwardTitle: Electrodes for Large Area Electronics Based on Partially Oxidized Graphene

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The concept of large area electronics builds on facile solution processing and inexpensive raw materials. Towards this end, the project has two primary technical tasks. In the first task, we intend to thoroughly characterize and optimize a novel form of solution processable graphene that has superior optical and electrical properties. In the second task, we intend to demonstrate a facile patterning method for integration into large area organic electronics. The intellectual merit of the proposal arises from its materials science impact ? a realistic material that is transparent, flexible, solution processable and can be readily implemented as universal electrodes in a variety of organic electronics devices has yet to be demonstrated. The broader impacts of the proposed project arise from the societal impact of a fast switching and low power consuming electronics that are inexpensive will be tremendous. Large area electronics are used in wide ranging consumer devices and the use of reduced graphene electrodes could lead to devices that would encourage more standby operations, save energy and extend battery life. The educational goals of this proposal are to provide research experience for undergraduates, provide laboratory modules for K ? 12 teachers that can be demonstrated in schools, and to participate in the enrichment activities of the Nanotechnology for Clean Energy IGERT Program (Director is the PI of this proposal). In addition to the above, an active international collaboration is planned with Imperial College London.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project dealt with creation of new electrodes based on 2D materials. The intellectual merit of the proposed work was to develop flexible electrodes for electronics using solution processable graphene and related 2D materials. This project has led to several publications, including two in Nature Materials. It trained one PhD student who won the MRS Gold Graduate Student Award (see highlight 1) and partially funded another. The work has resulted in development of novel, low contact resistance electrodes based on phase engineering of 2D materials for field effect transistors. This is an important contribution in the field of 2D transistors because it provides one strategy for achieving low contact resistances. Traditional doping and regrowth schemes used in 3D semiconductors cannot be used to achieve good contacts in 2D materials and therefore these results serve as a major breakthrough. The funding has also led to the discovery of using 2D materials as electrodes for catalysis to efficiently generate hydrogen for clean energy applications. The project was a catalyst for initiating a robust collaboration with Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL). The graduate student spend approximaely one year at LANL to carry out experiments and fabricate devices. This experience served to broaden the training of the graduate student by allowing him to access new equipment and develop relationships with new cohort of scientists.


Last Modified: 09/24/2015
Modified by: Manish Chhowalla

Image
  • Rajesh Kappera, the graduate student funded on this project, receiving the MRS Gold Graduate Student Award from the MRS President at the Fall 2014 Meeting. The Award for his paper on low contact resistance source and drain electrodes in transistors based on 2D materials.
    Manish Chhowalla
    Public Domain
    Manish Chhowalla
    Rajesh Kappera Graduate Student Award
